Mindfulness Journaling: To deal with the jealousy, try incorporating mindfulness journaling into your daily routine. Write down your thoughts and feelings without judgment, focusing on the present moment. This can help you become more aware of your emotions and understand why you feel jealous when others finish their tasks quickly. By acknowledging and accepting your emotions, you can learn to manage them more effectively.

Prioritize Your Tasks: To avoid feeling overwhelmed by the speed at which others complete their tasks, prioritize your own tasks more effectively. Make a list of all the tasks you need to complete and rank them in order of importance. Focus on completing the most critical tasks first, and break them down into smaller, manageable chunks. By prioritizing your tasks, you can avoid feeling overwhelmed and maintain a sense of control over your work.

Set Realistic Goals: To reduce feelings of jealousy, set realistic goals for yourself, both short-term and long-term. Break down larger tasks into smaller, achievable goals, and celebrate each success along the way. By setting realistic goals, you can build momentum and develop a sense of accomplishment, rather than feeling discouraged by the speed at which others complete their tasks.

Practice Gratitude: To combat jealousy, try practicing gratitude by focusing on the things you are thankful for in your life. Take a few minutes each day to reflect on the things that bring you joy and fulfillment. By focusing on the positive aspects of your life, you can shift your perspective and reduce feelings of jealousy.

Take Breaks: Finally, when you feel jealous of others' productivity, take a break and do something that brings you joy. Whether it's going for a walk, reading a book, or chatting with a friend, taking a break can help you recharge and refocus. By taking breaks, you can avoid burnout and maintain a healthy work-life balance, which can help reduce feelings of jealousy.
